text:
`SEO question`: what if an article is doing reasonably well, snagged a featured snippet, but you *know* it could be further improved and optimized? Is it better not to do it to avoid losing the snippet, “if it ain’t broken don’t fix it” style? :thinking_face:

I’d love to hear your thoughts! :thought_balloon:

elements.text: SEO question
: what if an article is doing reasonably well, snagged a featured snippet, but you
know
it could be further improved and optimized? Is it better not to do it to avoid losing the snippet, “if it ain’t broken don’t fix it” style?
I’d love to hear your thoughts!

text: <@U0125MKEXFS>

It’s indeed unacceptable and I’d never do that to a candidate. I did experience a lot of it in the past — it’s, unfortunately, quite common where I live (Berlin, Germany).

Hang in there! Respectful companies that value candidates are still out there, even though it sometimes seems to be all but wishful thinking.

elements.text:

text: I’d say that also heavily depends on the country you live in. The average would be much lower in Germany.

elements.text: I’d say that also heavily depends on the country you live in. The average would be much lower in Germany.

text: Hey—I would do this:

elements.text: Hey—I would do this:

text: • Check what Google is pulling out for the snippet and DO NOT touch that section

elements.text: Check what Google is pulling out for the snippet and DO NOT touch that section

text:
• The keyword you are getting a snippet for: do not alter instances of that keyword anywhere on the page 
• But go ahead and optimize → one post could get more than one snippet, depending on the keyword, so that’s an opportunity you don’t want to miss! 
• Monitor, and be prepared to revert back

elements.text: The keyword you are getting a snippet for: do not alter instances of that keyword anywhere on the page
But go ahead and optimize → one post could get more than one snippet, depending on the keyword, so that’s an opportunity you don’t want to miss!
Monitor, and be prepared to revert back

text: context: I have pieces that rank 1-3 for huge keywords (think: customer experience, website analysis, etc.) and I keep tinkering, adding FAQs, internal links, etc. :wink:

elements.text: context: I have pieces that rank 1-3 for huge keywords (think: customer experience, website analysis, etc.) and I keep tinkering, adding FAQs, internal links, etc.

text: This is _exactly_ the advice we wanted to hear. Thank you <@U017WRJTKF1> :smile:

text: Indeed! Many thanks, <@U017WRJTKF1>! :raised_hands::skin-tone-4:

elements.text: Indeed! Many thanks,

text:
I’m with <@U017WRJTKF1> on this, keep on improving it if you see potential but don’t touch the part that’s pulled for the Featured Snippet. Many pages that perform well in organic search are ranking for thousands of queries, so of course there’s room to optimize.

Earlier this week I was re-evaluating an article that was ranking 1st across the board for the most important terms and I just didn’t touch it, even though some of the things I did in that article didn’t adhere to the best practices. That was a case of “if it ain’t broken don’t fix it”.

text:
Hey :wave:.

Is there any SaaS newsletter that stood out for you and you'd gladly recommend to anyone?

What makes the newsletter unique to you? And what would you like to see less of in SaaS newsletters? 

 I'd love to chat with you for a post I'm working on. Feel free to reach me via DM or comment below.

Thanks:grinning:.

text: <@U01616TECAJ> Thank you! Ironically, I applied for a job in Düsseldorf on a whim last summer (I’m an American and have always wanted to live abroad), and after 3 rounds of interviews, they told me within 48 hours that they were moving forward with other candidates. Obviously, it wasn’t what I wanted to hear, but I was so impressed with their communication throughout the process, especially with the time difference.

text:
Here's my basic framework for this.

Awareness :point_right: "What is...?" (Answer general questions on the subj that your product solves for)

Consideration :point_right: "How to..." (How to do a task that your product solves)

Decision :point_right: "Here's why..." (Product comparisons, alternatives)

I did this pretty successfully at ClickUp (no longer there) but they've had really good organic growth

text: Yeah for sure. LOTS of gold in the comments as well. The biggest take-home for me, was that most “curated“ newsletters are not curated at all. They are just a list of every random podcast and blog post the person can find.

text:
<@U01704F04QH>, when you say SaaS newsletter, I assume you mean a newsletter distributed by a SaaS company, correct?
I don’t know if I have a favorite company newsletter. My favorite SaaS newsletters are all by VCs. I’ve asked myself many times how companies can adopt elements of these newsletters to make their own newsletters more effective:
• Openview: Love how they have leaned hard into category creation by building so much of their content around product-led growth. Newsletter always hits Saturday morning. I’m frequently on my way or at kids’ soccer when I open it up. I don’t read all the articles, but I am much more likely to skim and pull out for later than newsletters coming in the week. Also, they produce their own great content but also curate relevant stories from others.
• First Round Capital (first round review): Newsletter is usually focused on a single feature story. The way they format and tell these stories is super formulaic (and brilliant). The story telling is so good, I don’t mind that I know how each article will roll out. Things I love: 1) the feature story is about a tech leader. 2) By telling the tech leader’s story they also share insight on a tech related topic.
• Tomasz Tunguz: This newsletter is simply his latest blog post sent to blog subscribers. It does include “recent story” links, as well, but I almost never look at those. There is an element of surprise in these newsletters because the topics covered are so wide ranging. This could be a +/- depending on audience. Two other things I love about this newsletter are 1) topics always feel timely. 2) almost all posts include data to back up the theme of the post.

elements.text:
, when you say SaaS newsletter, I assume you mean a newsletter distributed by a SaaS company, correct?
I don’t know if I have a favorite company newsletter. My favorite SaaS newsletters are all by VCs. I’ve asked myself many times how companies can adopt elements of these newsletters to make their own newsletters more effective:

Openview: Love how they have leaned hard into category creation by building so much of their content around product-led growth. Newsletter always hits Saturday morning. I’m frequently on my way or at kids’ soccer when I open it up. I don’t read all the articles, but I am much more likely to skim and pull out for later than newsletters coming in the week. Also, they produce their own great content but also curate relevant stories from others.

First Round Capital (first round review): Newsletter is usually focused on a single feature story. The way they format and tell these stories is super formulaic (and brilliant). The story telling is so good, I don’t mind that I know how each article will roll out. Things I love: 1) the feature story is about a tech leader. 2) By telling the tech leader’s story they also share insight on a tech related topic.

Tomasz Tunguz: This newsletter is simply his latest blog post sent to blog subscribers. It does include “recent story” links, as well, but I almost never look at those. There is an element of surprise in these newsletters because the topics covered are so wide ranging. This could be a +/- depending on audience. Two other things I love about this newsletter are 1) topics always feel timely. 2) almost all posts include data to back up the theme of the post.

Even if they are not SaaS companies, I can take lessons from what they are doing so well. Thanks once again.
